content:
• Tuesday, March 15, 2016
  • AVID

    Avid gains after reporting strong bookings, issuing 2016-2018 guidance

    • While AVID Technology's Q4 revenue rose a moderate 9% Y/Y to $140M and missed estimates, bookings rose 26% to $193M, a marked improvement from Q3's 2.6% growth. 55% of bookings involved recurring revenue streams, up from 28% in Q3 and 42% a year ago.
    • The professional video hardware/software firm has also guided for 2016 bookings of $500M-$536M and adjusted free cash flow of $2M-$12M (improved from 2015's -$35.3M). Bookings are expected to respectively total $515M-$552M and $530M-$569M in 2017 and 2018, with adjusted FCF growing to $25M-$40M and $40M-$60M.
    • Avid expects Q1 revenue of $120M-$125M vs. a $123.7M consensus, and 2016 revenue of $500M-$525M vs. a $525.6M consensus.
    • Paid subscribers rose by over 7,500 in Q4 to more than 25K. Users of Avid's MediaCentral platform rose by over 4K Q/Q to more than 32K.
    • AVID +6.1% after hours to $7.10.
    • Avid's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 PM
  • CAS

    A.M. Castle sells plastics unit for $55M

    • A.M. Castle (CAS -5.8%) has wrapped the sale of its Total Plastics unit for about $55M.
    • The company sold the subsidiary to Texas-based Prophet Equity, "yet another significant step in our commitment to delever our balance sheet and improve the capital structure and profitability of our business,” says CEO Steven Scheinkman.
    • Castle will use the proceeds to pay down debt. In the deal, $1.5M of the price is put into escrow pending a working-capital adjustment to be determined within 60 days.
    • In its last report, the company had total debt of $322.7M, a debt/equity ratio of 793, and just under $12M in cash.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:27 PM
  • CIVI

    Civitas grows into Maryland with adult day health acquisition

    • Home and community-based healthcare provider Civitas Solutions (CIVI -3.7%) has expanded into Maryland with the purchase of five Adult Day Health centers.
    • Those centers generated revenues of about $12M over the past 12 months. The centers provide "person-centered" day services (medication management, nutritional/nursing support) to elders.
    • The company had identified Maryland as a candidate for expansion after moving into an adjacent ADH market, CEO Bruce Nardella says. It got into the $6.2B market with a September 2014 acquisition of the Mass Adult Day Health Alliance.
    • Meanwhile, West Virginia has signed a law terminating its behavioral health severance and business privilege tax, which should provide relief to behavior health organizations including Civitas (which currently pays the state $230K/month in the tax).
    • Shares are flat in after-hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:47 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: XELB +6.8%. AVID +5.8%. ORCL +5.3%. ACOR +5.1%. XIN +4.6%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: OCIP -8.3%. CAL -8.2%. CONE -6.1%. HMY -5.4%. NUAN -3.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM | 1 Comment
  • TARO

    Taro Pharmaceutical launches $250M buyback

    • Taro Pharmaceutical (TARO -2.9%) has signed off on a new $250M share repurchase program.
    • The company's not setting a time period or expiration date for the program. As typical, purchases can be made on the open market, negotiated transactions, 10b5-1 trading plans or otherwise.
    • At its last report, Taro had $1.18B in cash on its balance sheet, with no debt.
    • Shares are flat in after-hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:36 PM | 8 Comments
  • OCIP

    OCI Partners to delay 10-K filing, sees 23% drop in 2015 revenues

    • OCI Partners (NYSE:OCIP) -11.8% AH after filing to delay its 10-K filing and offering preliminary FY 2015 results.
    • OCIP says it could not file the 10-K on time since it had been working with its lenders to amend certain provisions of its existing credit facility related to the expectation that it will not satisfy all financial covenants for measurement dates past March 31.
    • OCIP expects FY 2015 revenues of $309M vs. $403M for 2014, with the reduction due primarily to a decrease in the average sales price per ton of methanol and ammonia, and EBITDA of $123M vs. $163M for 2014.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:19 PM
  • EVHC

    Envision Healthcare acquiring Midwest emergency doctor group

    • Envision Healthcare (EVHC -4.4%) has a definitive deal to acquire Michigan-based Emergency Physicians Medical Group.
    • EVHC expects to invest $120M along with contingent consideration in the acquisition. EPMG is expected to contribute annualized net revenues of about $140M.
    • EPMG operates 37 facilities across the Midwest and in Delaware, with more than 500 clinical providers managing 1M patient encounters annually.
    • The deal's expected to close within 30 days.
    • Envision also said its American Medical Response transport segment has three new deals with large health systems and will add basic life support services in the Washington, D.C., metro area later this month. Those deals are expected to bring $45M in annualized revenues.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:11 PM
  • CALL

    MagicJack VocalTec slides 7.2% after Q4 revenue miss

    • MagicJack VocalTec (CALL +10.3%) has slid 7.2% in postmarket trading following a Q4 earnings report where net revenues fell 4% and missed slightly.
    • EBITDA was $9.2M, beating an expected $8.9M.
    • Revenue breakout: Net revenues from device sales were $3.8M; access rights renewal revenues were $15.9M (65% of total); prepaid minutes, $1.8M; access and wholesale charges, $1.6M; other, $1.4M.
    • At year-end, an estimated 2.44M active magicJack subscribers. The company activated 105,000 subs in Q4. Average monthly churn was 2.7% for the quarter.
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM
  • PEB

    Strong session for Pebblebrook Hotel after dividend hike

    • Moving nicely higher today while the rest of the lodging REIT sector was in the red was Pebblebrook Hotel Trust (PEB +2.7%), which boosted its quarterly dividend by 22.6% to $0.38 per share.
    • Its stock roughed-up for the last year-plus along with those of the rest of the hotel REITs, the company nevertheless continues to churn out funds from operations well north of its payout.
    • Previously: Pebblebrook Hotel guides for about 10% FFO growth in 2016 (Feb. 22)
    • Previously: Pebblebrook Hotel beats by $0.03, beats on revenue (Feb. 22)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM

  • API: Oil inventory build lower than expected

    • U.S. crude supplies rose 1.5M barrels in the week ended March 11, according to the API, vs. expectations for a 2.7M barrel build.
    • The EIA releases its estimate tomorrow.
    • Oil has moved higher since the news hit, now at $36.77 per barrel vs. $36.40 a few minutes ago, and a low earlier in the day at about $36.
    • USO +0.7% after hours
    • ETFs: USO, OIL, UCO, UWTI, SCO, BNO, DWTI, DBO, DTO, UGA, USL, DNO, UHN, OLO, SZO, OLEM
     
     
     
     
    | 4:53 PM | 19 Comments
  • CMG

    Chipotle reports weak February comps, issues Q1 warning; shares drop

    • With a recent spate of customer illnesses still weighing and free burrito offers only doing so much to help, Chipotle's (NYSE:CMG) comparable restaurant sales fell 26.1% Y/Y in February (28.7% excluding February's leap day), after having dropped 36.4% in January. (8-K filing)
    • Comps were down 33.8% during the first two weeks of February, and 24.7% over the last two weeks (excluding the leap day). They were down 21.5% during the week ending March 7, and 27.3% during the following week.
    • The fast-casual chain now expects a mid-single digit Q1 restaurant-level op. margin, and Q1 EPS of -$1.00 or worse. The EPS consensus is at $0.11.
    • Chipotle: "During the quarter we will incur higher expenses driven by increased marketing and promotions spend in other operating costs, which are anticipated to be significantly higher in the first half of 2016 compared to historic reporting periods. We also anticipate higher food costs due to additional food safety protocols put into place, as well as higher food costs related to food waste, rejection rates related to high resolution DNA testing, and lower volumes. We have also incurred higher labor costs to ensure we were fully staffed as customers redeemed their free burrito offer."
    • CMG -3.2% after hours to $486.82.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:43 PM | 31 Comments
  • XELB

    Xcel Brands EPS in-line, misses on revenue

    • Xcel Brands (NASDAQ:XELB): Q4 EPS of $0.10 in-line.
    • Revenue of $7.47M (+31.3% Y/Y) misses by $0.46M.
    • Shares +7.66%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:38 PM
  • TWER

    Towerstream misses on 2015 revenues; focusing on cash burn

    • Rooftop cellular company Towerstream (TWER +9.6%) has closed the books on a fiscal year earnings report where revenues fell short of expectations and the company faced an impending delisting.
    • “Our immediate focus is to reduce cash burn, and to ignite the On-Net sales model,” says interim CEO Philip Urso. The co-founder of the company, Urso took over as interim CEO last month.
    • Cash burn for Q2 is expected to be under $2.9M. HetNets Tower Corp. has closed operations, Towerstream says, effective immediately.
    • Continuing revenues of $27.9M fell 6.8%; including discontinued operations, consolidated revenues were $31.28M. The company was expected to log $31.7M in revenues.
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM
  • ORCL

    Oracle adds $10B to buyback and declares dividend; shares higher post-earnings

    • Oracle (NYSE:ORCL) has used its FQ3 report (revenue missed, EPS beat) to announce it's adding $10B to its buyback authorization. The new funds are good for repurchasing 6% of shares at current levels. $8.5B was spent on common stock repurchases over the first 9 months of FY16, with over $2B spent in FQ3 (boosted EPS).
    • The software giant has also declared its regular $0.15/share quarterly dividend (1.5% yield). The next dividend is payable on April 28 to shareholders on record as of April 14.
    • Top-line performance: Op-premise software + cloud revenue fell 1% Y/Y in FQ3, and rose 3% in constant currency (within a 3%-4% guidance range). On-premise software revenue fell 4% to $6.3B, a smaller decline than FQ2's 7%. Cloud revenue rose 40% to $735M, an improvement (thanks to strong prior bookings) from FQ2's 26%. Hardware revenue fell 13% to $1.1B, and other services revenue fell 7% to $793M. Forex had a 400 bps impact on revenue growth (-3% Y/Y vs. +1%)

      Within on-premise, new software license revenue (hurt by cloud adoption) fell a steep 15% Y/Y to $1.7B. Software license update/product support revenue (driven by past license deals) was flat at $4.7B. Within cloud, SaaS/PaaS (cloud apps and app platforms, an Oracle priority) revenue rose 57% to $583M; IaaS (cloud infrastructure, faces tough competition from Amazon and others) revenue fell 2% to $152M. SaaS/PaaS bookings rose 77% Y/Y in constant currency. Mark Hurd and Larry Ellison once more trash-talk Salesforce and Workday.
    • Financials: Lifting EPS: GAAP costs/expenses rose just 1% Y/Y to $6B, thanks partly to a 23% drop in amortization expenses to $408M. Sales/marketing spend rose 3% to $1.9B, R&D 4% to $1.4B, and G&A 15% to $290M. Oracle ended FQ3 with $51B in cash/investments (much of it offshore) and $40B in debt.
    • ORCL +3.9% after hours to $40.23. Conference call at 5PM ET (webcast), guidance should be provided.
    • Oracle's FQ3 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:26 PM | 2 Comments
  • FELP

    Foresight Energy -25% after suspending distribution, warning of bankruptcy

    • Foresight Energy (FELP -25.2%) falls sharply after reporting a large Q4 loss, canceling its quarterly distribution, suspending forward guidance, and warning it could be forced into file Chapter 11 bankruptcy unless it can reach a restructuring deal with its lenders.
    • FELP says it has been continuing talks with the holders of its senior notes due 2021 after a Delaware court ruled prior transactions with Murray Energy triggered a change of control of the company, securing forbearance agreement sset to expire today keeping the noteholders from exercising those rights.
    • Barring an extension of the agreements or some other deal, FELP says it likely would have no other choice than to petition for bankruptcy relief.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:09 PM
  • MNK

    Mallinckrodt tumbles alongside Valeant as Citron chimes in

    • Valeant looks like a choirboy next to Mallinckrodt (MNK -15.2%), Citron Research's Andrew Left tells CNBC. "At least Valeant can say, 'Hey, look at our products.' Mallinckrodt has one product that's never been tested."
    • Previously: Valeant's credibility on the rocks after disastrous earnings call (March 15)
    • Previously: Mallinckrodt feels Andrew Left's sting; down 17% (Nov. 9, 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:53 PM | 19 Comments
  • AMD

    AMD unveils Radeon Pro Duo, Polaris 10/11, 2017/2018 GPU roadmap; shares fall

    • AMD (AMD -8.6%) has followed up on yesterday morning's VR announcements by revealing (at a Game Developers Conference event) the Radeon Pro Duo, a high-end dual-GPU solution declared by the company to be "the world's most powerful platform for virtual reality."
    • The Duo, previously expected to be called the Fury X2 - the first Fury GPUs launched last June - is expected to sport a $1,499 MSRP, and is aimed at both hardcore gamers and professionals (including VR content creators). Each of its GPUs sport 4096 stream processors and are paired with 4GB of High Bandwidth Memory delivering 512GB/s of memory bandwidth. Total performance is pegged at 16 TFLOPs.
    • AMD also provided details about its Polaris 10 and 11 GPUs, which are due in mid-2016 and will rely on Samsung/Globalfoundries' 14nm FinFET manufacturing process - Polaris was first revealed at CES. The company reiterates its claim Polaris will deliver massive improvements in performance/watt.
    • WCCFTech estimates a Polaris video card shown off in a demo consumes only 50W of power, making it twice as power-efficient as a card using Nvidia's (NVDA -1.3%) GTX 950 GPU (based on the 28nm Maxwell architecture). Nvidia plans to counter Polaris with GPUs based on its 16nm Pascal architecture; the company promises a 2x performance/watt increase over Maxwell, and support for up to 12TFLOPs of performance, 32GB of HBM and 1 TB/s of memory bandwdith.
    • In 2017, AMD plans to launch GPUs based on Vega, an architecture supporting HBM2 memory (supports higher densities and more memory bandwidth). Vega will be followed in 2018 by Navi, an architecture said to support an unnamed next-gen memory type.
    • AMD has fully given back yesterday's gains. The Nasdaq is down 0.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:12 PM | 17 Comments
  • ZLIOY

    Reuters: Zoomlion sweetens offer for Terex

    • Zoomlion (OTCPK:ZLIOY) has raised its takeover offer for Terex (TEX +7%) to more than $3.4B by adding a $1/share special dividend to its previous $30/share cash offer, and TEX has responded by asking for $32.75/share in cash to agree to sell itself to Zoomlion and terminate its merger agreement with Konecranes, Reuters reports.
    • The main stumbling block is the price, rather than concerns that the U.S. could block the deal because of TEX's ties to the U.S. military and presence in U.S. ports, according to the report.
    • The discussions have not advanced beyond price, and Zoomlion's banks are waiting for TEX to provide access required for their due diligence in order to finalize their financing commitments, Reuters says.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:05 PM | 7 Comments
  • BHC

    Valeant's credibility on the rocks after disastrous earnings call

    • As far as bad days go, the management team at Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX -46.4%) is, no doubt, having a whopper. Shares cratered after this morning's Q4 and 2015 earnings call, which virtually obliterated whatever prior credibility existed.
    • Another bullet hole in the slide presentation pertained to top seller Xifaxan (rifaximin). Q4 revenue was only $210M, significantly lower than management's $390M projection in December. This seriously questions the validity of the company's 2016 sales outlook of $1B and undermines management's grasp of the business. Not helping matters was the recent departure of VP/company group chairman Deb Jorn whose responsibilities included Xifaxan.
    • Previously: Valeant dermatology/gastrointestinal chief resigns (March 2)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:47 PM | 13 Comments
  • TIF

    Citi to the sidelines on Tiffany for the near term

    • Citi is the latest Wall Street firm to turn cautious on Tiffany (TIF -2.5%) with a cut to Neutral from Buy.
    • Analyst Paul Lejuez says near-term earnings drivers are hard to spot. He expects full-year guidance to be "back-end weighted" when Tiffany reports results later this week. The FQ4 consensus estimates are $1.209B in revenue and EPS of $1.40.
    • Citi's new price target on the jewelry seller is $78 (comfortably above today's trading level).
     
     
     
     
    | 1:22 PM
  • XONE

    ExOne tumbles after earnings delay, guidance reiteration

    • A day after surging in sympathy with 3D Systems, ExOne (XONE -9.8%) is seeing steep losses after pushing back its Q4 earnings release by a week to March 22 and reiterating its 2015 sales/shipment guidance.
    • Volume is strong, but not huge - 255K shares vs. a 3-month full-day average of 271K. There could be some disappointment ExOne didn't hike its guidance in the wake of 3D Systems' and Stratasys' Q4 beats. The 3D printer maker trades for 4.3x its 2015 sales guidance of $40M.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:00 PM
  • PSTR

    PostRock Energy receives notice of acceleration

    • PostRock Energy (OTC:PSTR -48%) is cut nearly in half after its lenders accelerate the balance of the company's indebtedness, making the entire outstanding principal balance and all accrued interest immediately due and payable.
    • PSTR says it continues to analyze various alternative methods to monetize its assets but that any proceeds would be substantially less than the amount required to fully repay its debt, and its stockholders would lose their entire investment.
    • Earlier: PostRock Energy violates its loan covenants (Feb. 25)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:59 PM
  • NHTC

    SA contributor posts pics of deserted Natural Health Trends office

    • Natural Health Trends (NASDAQ:NHTC) is down 5.5% on above-average volume amid questions on what's going on in China.
    • The latest: SA contributor TheGeoTeam posted an article in which it outlined why it believes a Beijing office of the company may have been shut down by authorities. The submission includes pics of a deserted office with a sign that says essentially it's closed for remodeling.
    • Natural Health Trends refuted earlier allegations made in January of any investigation.
    • Previously: Natural Health Trends -6% as rumors from China pop up (March 15)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:57 PM
  • CMTL

    Comtech gains after announcing $3.1M Navy contract

    • Comtech (CMTL +2.5%) has won a $3.1M contract extension to provide additional  advanced TDMA interface processor (ATIP) terminals to the U.S. Navy.
    • Comtech: "The ATIP is a Layer-2 Ethernet bridging device installed on ship, shore and submarine platforms in the Navy Multiband Terminal (NMT). The ATIP program is providing significant improvements to the Advanced Extremely High Frequency (AEHF) system's performance through dynamic bandwidth management, support for higher XDR data rates, and increased throughput. Later next year, Comtech will deliver an Adaptive Coding capability to further improve the AEHF system's performance."
    • For reference, Comtech has an April quarter revenue consensus of $78M.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:54 PM

  • Midday Gainers/ Losers

    • Gainers: CPXX +335%. CHNR +58%. SZYM +21%. AXSM +19%. INGN +17%. WVE +14%. ARL +13%. CAPR +12%. CIFC +11%. AKER +10%.
    • Losers: VRX -47%. CSTM -35%. ZYNE -27%. RXDX -27%. CJES -21%. BLCM -19%. GBR -19%. NVIV -18%. PTX -18%. APPS -17%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM
  • RTK

    Rentech revises agreements with GSO to assist RNF-CVR merger closure

    • Rentech (RTK +4.4%) rises after GSO Capital Partners agrees to provide $6M in additional short-term liquidity if required prior to the closing of the pending merger between Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF -1.7%) and CVR Partners (UAN -2.8%).
    • GSO also agrees to revise its existing waiver and amendment agreement with RTK, which the company says is intended to enable the merger to close without regard to whether RTK receives units in CVR sufficient to repay a fixed amount of preferred stock and debt held by GSO.
    • Separately, RNF says it sold its Pasadena, Tex., facility to Pasadena Commodities International, the plant's long-time distributor for ammonium sulfate.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:49 PM | 1 Comment
  • BHC

    Pershing Square still believes in value of Valeant but not in current management

    • The dramatic plunge in Valeant Pharmaceuticals' (VRX -46.8%) stock price after this morning's earnings call prompts Pershing Square's Bill Ackman to send a letter to shareholders, no doubt experiencing considerable pain considering Pershing's substantial stake in the drug firm.
    • In the letter, he states that management "shocked the market" with its lowered revenue and sales guidance which appears to contradict continued favorable prescription trends and executives' bullish comments about the strength of the underlying business.
    • He goes on to state that his fund intends to take a "much more proactive role" at the firm (Vice Chairman Steve Fraidin recently joined the board) in order to realize its true value, conditional on "restoring shareholder confidence in the management and governance of the company." Sounds like Mr. Ackman has lost confidence in CEO Michael Pearson.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM | 25 Comments
  • OAS

    J.P. Morgan upgrades Oasis Petroleum, downgrades Whiting after oil rally

    • Oasis Petroleum (OAS -5.1%) is upgraded to Overweight with a $9 price target, raised from $6, at J.P. Morgan, which believes OAS is well positioned operationally vs. peers and that the company’s enhanced completions in the Bakken generate top-tier returns.
    • The firm also downgrades Whiting Petroleum (WLL -10.7%) to Neutral from Overweight with an $8 price target, primarily to reflect valuation after shares have surged 140% from their late-February low.
    • J.P. Morgan favors companies that can sustain or quickly re-establish positive operating momentum as the industry begins fighting the decline curve; its top picks are Callon Petroleum (CPE -2.7%), Diamondback Energy (FANG -1%), Newfield Exploration (NFX -2.9%), Parsley Energy (PE -0.4%) and PDC Energy (PDCE -0.9%).
     
     
     
     
    | 12:28 PM | 2 Comments
  • AXSM

    Axsome Therapeutics bags patent covering lead product candidate; shares up 18%

    • Thinly traded micro cap Axsome Therapeutics (AXSM +18.3%) is up on increased volume, albeit on turnover of only 32K shares, in response to its announcement that the USPTO has issued a new patent covering lead product candidate, AXS-02 (disodium zoledronate tetrahydrate), under development for the treatment of complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS). The composition of matter patent extends into 2034.
    • The company earned an earlier patent, in December 2015, covering oral uses of oral zoledronic acid which extends into 2033.
    • CRPS is a debilitating condition characterized by severe chronic throbbing or burning pain in a limb. It typically develops after an injury, surgery, stroke or heart attack. The pain is more severe than what would be expected for the type of injury or adverse event. There are no currently approved therapies for the disorder.
    • Orphan Drug- and Fast Track-tagged AXS-02 is a non-opioid pain medication that inhibits a type of bone cell that breaks down bone tissue called an osteoclast.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:20 PM
  • OUTR

    Outerwall +8.2% after strategic, dividend news; Roth upgrades

    • Outerwall (NASDAQ:OUTR) is up 8.2% today, echoing an after-hours gain yesterday when the company said it was exploring strategic alternatives and doubling its dividend.
    • The stock's gone positive for 2016, hitting its highest point since Dec. 30. And Roth Capital Partners has upgraded shares to Neutral from Sell. Its price target is $35 -- 1.8% above yesterday's close and baked into the gain today.
    • “We believe logical alternatives could include shutdown of EcoATM, sale of Coin, or outright sale of the entire company, among others,” says Roth's Darren Aftahi.
    • He's not necessarily a fan of the dividend hike, though; free cash flow supports it, but he's rather see further deleveraging. The company carries total debt of $885.6M, with $222.6M of cash on the balance sheet.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:13 PM | 6 Comments
  • NE

    Noble Corp. downgraded at Susquehanna following recent rally

    • Noble Corp. (NE -4.1%) is downgraded to Neutral from Positive with an $11 price target at Susquehanna, a change the firm says has less to do with the specifics around NE and more to do with the challenges facing the offshore drilling industry during a time when customer budgets will be down sharply again in 2016.
    • Susquehanna says it views NE's 2016-17 contract coverage, relatively younger fleet vs. the industry, relatively strong balance sheet and experienced management team as advantages for the company relative to other offshore drillers.
    • With expectations of only marginal incremental demand for floaters over the next 12 months, the firm says it prefers to wait for greater visibility into a recovery in offshore spending or more attractive valuation before recommending the stock.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM | 4 Comments
  • GWRE

    Guidewire slumps after naming new sales chief

    • Steven Sherry, formerly Guidewire's (GWRE -2.6%) Americas sales chief, is now the company's SVP of worldwide sales. He's now responsible for "Guidewire’s worldwide sales, sales operations, customer relationship management, and partner alliances organizations."
    • Sherry succeeds Scott Roza, who had been the insurance software firm's SVP of worldwide sales since 2013 and its chief customer officer since last year. Roza is now Guidewire's chief business officer, a role that (per Guidewire's exec bio page) gives him oversight of "Guidewire’s worldwide customer facing team which includes sales, pre-sales consulting, value consulting, customer relationship management, and partner alliances."
    • Two weeks ago: Guidewire jumps after FQ2 beat, strong FY16 EPS guidance
     
     
     
     
    | 11:56 AM
  • EGY

    Vaalco Energy gets $19M from Angolan partner, to delay filing 10-K

    • Vaalco Energy (EGY -4.1%) gives up early gains that followed news it had received $19M cash from its partner in Angola, Sonangol P&P, which represents the full amount due for its share of past costs outstanding, including interest, at Dec. 31.
    • EGY says it will temporarily delay the filing of its financial statements to reflect the development.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:49 AM
  • BHC

    Valeant management doesn't have a handle on the health of its own business - Piper

    • "Valeant (VRX) reported 4Q15 adjusted revenue and EPS of $2.8B and $2.50, respectively, but more importantly issued 2016 guidance that was well below the ranges that management had withdrawn on 2/28/16.
    • "Further, the ever-shifting commentary from VRX surrounding a number of segments in our view suggests that management simply does not have a handle on the health of its own business.
    • "Given the persistent uncertainty over the trajectory of a number of key segments, along with the reality of high debt levels and specifically myriad debt covenants (specifically, financial reporting covenants in the near-term; i.e.,
      the specter of multiple defaults if the company cannot file its 10K in the near-term), we are moving to an Underweight rating from a Neutral.
    • "Our PT continues to be suspended given the absence of audited financials."
    • Source: Piper Jaffray
    • VRX -44% to $38.60.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:33 AM | 15 Comments
  • PERI

    Perion sells off after issuing post-acquisition 2016 guidance

    • Perion (PERI -8.2%) is lower after beating Q4 estimates, guiding for Q1 revenue of $69M-$71M (up from $52.1M a year earlier), and guiding for 50%+ 2016 revenue growth. Consensus, which doesn't appear to fully account for Perion's $180M December acquisition of ad services firm Undertone, is for Q1 revenue of $53.2M and 31% revenue growth. 2016 EBITDA margin guidance is at 10%-12%.
    • Top-line performance: Search revenue (toolbar-driven) fell 37% Y/Y in Q4 to $43.1M - Perion says it's trying to lower customer acquisition costs and focus on premium publishers. Ad/other revenue, boosted by the acquisitions of Undertone and social media ad platform MakeMeReach, rose 145% to $24.5M. Perion expects to get close to half its 2016 revenue from Undertone and MakeMeReach.
    • Financials: Non-GAAP costs and expenses (excludes content acquisition and media buy costs) were $27.3M (42% of revenue) vs. $25.3M (32% of revenue) a year ago.     • CEO Sergey Solonin: "In [Q4] we continued to see the pressure from both the macroeconomic slowdown in Russia resulting in weaker consumer finance market and lower demand for money remittance services due to shifting migration trends, and stricter regulation of the agents network ...     • The board has approved a $0.50/share dividend that will be paid on March 31 to shareholders on record as of March 29. Qiwi: "We continue to pursue certain M&A targets, thus our view on dividends distribution throughout 2016 is subject to change."
    • Q4 metrics: Total payment volume (boosted by the Contact/Rapida acquisitions) rose 37% Y/Y to RUR239.5B ($3.3B). Active Visa Qiwi Wallet accounts fell by 6% to 16.1M.     • Financials: Though up 8% Y/Y in rubles to RUR2.66B, adjusted net revenue fell 17% in dollars to $36.5M. Adjusted net profit rose 44% in rubles to RUR860M, and 11% in dollars to $11.8M. SG&A spend rose 10% Y/Y to RUR1.26B ($15.7M). Qiwi ended 2015 with $266M in cash and $45M in debt.

  • BHC

    Valeant Q4 earnings call notes

    • Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) Q4 GAAP EPS was loss of $0.98; non-GAAP CF Ops: $838M versus guidance of >$600M.
    • Negative impact of $0.80 per shares due to underperformance in several key areas. Lower growth rate expected in GI and Dermatology.
    • Walgreens deal off to strong start, accounting for 30% of Dermatology volume (turned on Jan. 15). Activity-based fee schedule. GI not a part of the program.
    • Company will institute a cost reduction program, including the divestment of underperforming assets. Sale of Synergetics contract manufacturing and surgical neurology businesses expected to close in Q2.
    • Updated 2016 non-GAAP EPS outlook: $8.50 - 9.50 (down from $13.25 - 13.75 in December). More conservative assumptions going forward. Double-digit growth areas: GI, Dendreon, Dentistry, Contact Lens, Women's Health.
    • Downward adjustment of expected revenues led by GI, Dermatology and Neurology (-$800M) and other U.S. (-$300M).
    • Leading growth platforms: Xifaxan, Emerging Markets, Ultra/Biotrue, Latanoprostene bunod, IDP-118, Brodalumab.
    • Paying down debt a priority in 2016. Goal: pay down $1.7B this year.
    • Walgreens pricing to be discounted 10%. Aggressive price increases will no longer be the norm. Almost all planned price increases canceled for this year.
    • Price inflation protection a part of managed care contracts.
    • Based on new tax reporting approach: Q1 non-GAAP EPS outlook: $1.18 - 1.43. Under old tax reporting: $1.30 - 1.55. New tax reporting involves non-GAAP adjustments, timing items and use of certain tax attributes.
